import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

source.6bb4df28:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import plotly.express as px
source.169b1f00:
lab = 'No','Yes'
plt.pie(df['Survived'].value_counts(), labels = lab, autopct='%1.1f%%')
plt.title('Survival Status')
plt.show()
source.e111b6d0:
lab = '3rd','1st','2nd'
plt.pie(df['Pclass'].value_counts(), labels = lab, autopct='%1.1f%%')
plt.title('Ticket class')
plt.show()
source.4e75c58c:
df2=pd.pivot_table(df, index=['Pclass'], columns=['Survived'], values=['PassengerId'], aggfunc='count')
print(df2,'\n')

df3=df2.div(df2.sum(1).astype(float), axis=0)
print(df3) 

plt.figure()
(df3*100).plot.bar(title='Ticket class vs. Survival Status', stacked=True)
plt.xlabel('Ticket class')
plt.ylabel('Passenger %')
source.ab6e84da:
lab = 'Male','Female'
plt.pie(df['Sex'].value_counts(), labels = lab, autopct='%1.1f%%')
plt.title('Gender')
plt.show()

source.76cd1113:
print(df['Age'].describe())
sns.distplot(df['Age'],color='darkblue')
plt.title('Age in years')
plt.show()
source.d8332bc0:
sns.boxplot(x="Survived", y="Age",data=df, palette=('red','yellow'))
plt.title('Age in years vs. Survival Status')
plt.show()
source.569ae065:
df1 = df.groupby(["SibSp"]).count().reset_index()

fig = px.bar(df1,
             y=df.groupby(["SibSp"]).size()/len(df)*100,
             x="SibSp")
fig.update_layout(yaxis_title='percentage',
                  title_text='Number of siblings / spouses aboard the Titanic')
fig.show()
source.93fb0469:

print(df3) 

plt.figure()

source.b520435f:
df1 = df.groupby(["Parch"]).count().reset_index()

fig = px.bar(df1,
             y=df.groupby(["Parch"]).size()/len(df)*100,
             x="Parch")
fig.update_layout(yaxis_title='percentage',
                  title_text='Number of parents / children aboard the Titanic')
fig.show()

source.53486f79:

plt.title('Passenger fare vs. Survival Status')
plt.show()
source.b03ac6d8:
lab = 'Southampton','Cherbourg','Queenstown'
plt.pie(df['Embarked'].value_counts(), labels = lab, autopct='%1.1f%%')
plt.title('Port of Embarkation')
plt.show()
source.d6f9adf1:
df2=pd.pivot_table(df, index=['Embarked'], columns=['Survived'], values=['PassengerId'], aggfunc='count')
print(df2,'\n')

df3=df2.div(df2.sum(1).astype(float), axis=0)
print(df3) 

plt.figure()
(df3*100).plot.bar(title='Port of Embarkation vs. Survival Status', stacked=True)
plt.xlabel('Port of Embarkation')
plt.ylabel('Passenger %')
source.f02993b6: About 50% of passengers who had only one family connection survived. As the number of family contacts increases, the number of survivors decreases.
source.32fea291: This defines the family relations among the passengers in a way of parents and child. Nearly 75% of passengers were travelled without parents or children.
source.e435eb0b: ### Number of siblings / spouses aboard the Titanic
source.1a973167: Most of the titanic passengers (55.1%) were belong to the 3rd class which represent the lower socio-economic status (SES). There were 20.7% of passengers who belongs to the middle socio-economic status (2nd class) and, 24.2% of passengers who belongs to the upper socio-economic status (1st class).
source.dc08bd74: ### Port of Embarkation vs. Survival Status
source.c7303a1c: Males constitute 64.8% of the population and females 35.2%.
source.4c976f41: More than 50% of passengers who arrived from Cherbourg have survived, and 39% of passengers have survived who arrived from Queenstown. Only 33.7% of passengers could able to servive who arrived from Motherland of the Titanic. Many of the workers and staff came from the port of Southampton.
source.99ae9ce4: Almost 3/4 of female passengers were survived and, only 18.9% of male passengers were able to survive even though there were less number of male passengers.
source.8d143da7: Passengers arrived from the ports of Southampton, Cherbourg, and Queenstown  were aboard the Titanic. 72.4% of passengers have aboard in Southampton, England, the port where the voyage began.
source.551e2622: Unlike of the sibling spouse relationship, passengers with 3 family relationships have been able to survive. By the way, most of the passengers with this type of family connection have survived.
source.306f60fb: Survivors are more likely to be younger, but age alone does not seem to have much effect. As women have a greater chance of survival and they can represent all ages, this apparent difference may not be noticeable. However, according to legends, women as well as children had a better chance of survival.
source.bbfddb1a:
**Look and feel the characteristics of titanic passengers and the features of those who survived.**  
**Thank You!**
source.0e3fea16: Passengers age (in years) shows a symetric bell-shaped distribution. Very few children and adults were there.  Babies less than a year old were also among the passengers, with the oldest passenger being 80 years old. 50% of passengers were in between 20 years old and 38 years old.
source.ee8acd6b: ### Number of parents / children aboard the Titanic vs. Survival Status
source.c64ae678: Passenger fare shows a positively skewed distribution with a maximum fare of 512.3292. Workers and staff can be considered non-paying passengers
source.378dc3af:
Passenger ID and Name contain unique valus for each observation.  
Cabin number containe nearly 75% of null values and remaining observations are unique.  
Ticket number is a unique variable.
Therefore, remove PassengerId, Name, Ticket, and Cabin variables from the dataset.
source.8bfe49e7: ### Number of parents / children aboard the Titanic
source.e8a59722: ### Number of siblings / spouses aboard the Titanic vs. Survival Status
source.881f5d27: According to the dataset, 38.4% of passenger survived the Titanic accident and 61.6% were unable to survive.
source.fb982e5b: When considering the survival status with passenger's socio-economic status, more than 50% of pasengers who belongs to upper socio-economic status could have able to survive.  Fewer than 25% of low-socio-economic passengers survived.
source.b2ee32b4: This defines the family relations among the passengers in a way of siblings and spouse. Nearly 70% of passengers were without siblings or spouses.
source.a0aea667: It seems that many of those who paid the higher fare survived. This could be related with the socio-economic status as well. Those with higher fares may belong to higher socio-economic status and have a higher chance of survival.
